result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Complete 20 hours of community service
Participate in groups or day report at the discretion of day report manager
Complete AODA and follow treatment recommendations if there are any
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription
Do not possess any drug paraphernalia 
Do not associate with any persons possessing or consuming illegal controlled substances
Participate in any other community based services as determined by VIP director

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Samantha M. Brewington

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: letter from Mike Champion, VIP Program Director, dated 05/23/16 in re:  request to sucessfully discharge defendant from VIP program

Defendant Samantha M. Brewington in court with attorney Ryan Drengler. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

4:04 PM Court calls case.
Atty Knaapen states appearances.

Matter is set for a plea today.

Atty Knaapen states that Defendant will plead to Count 1.
Count 2 would be dismissed and read in.
Defendant is found to be an appropriate candidate for VIP Program for 6 months.

 Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 1.

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Drengler for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court does not find the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to WITHHOLD entry of Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 1: contrary to the statute section stated therein
Count 2: Dismissed and read in

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Drengler makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

Court agrees with recommendation, good candidate for VIP program.

BY THE COURT:
Count 1:
VIP Program for 6 months
Complete 20 hours of community service
Participate in groups or day report at the discretion of day report manager
Complete AODA and follow treatment recommendations if there are any
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription
Do not possess any drug paraphernalia 
Do not associate with any persons possessing or consuming illegal controlled substances
Participate in any other community based services as determined by VIP director

Defendant is to meet with Mr. Champion before leaving today.
VIP Program Assessment and Recommendation Report
